content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Jessica Johnson: I was born in Raleigh, North Carolina, and I've lived here most of my life, which has shaped a lot of who I am. Growing up, my parents were both working hard to make ends meet, and things were pretty tight financially. My parents divorced when I was around ten, and I remember that being a really tough time. I had to learn to be independent early on, and I often found myself helping out with household chores and taking care of my younger siblings when my mom was working late shifts. Education was always a priority for me, even though we didn't have a lot of resources. I worked part-time jobs through high school to help support the family, but I never let that stop me from excelling in school. I graduated high school and started working full-time right away, which has allowed me to build a stable life for myself. I'm proud of how far I've come, and I'm still figuring out what's next, but I know I've got a strong foundation to build on.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Jessica Johnson: There was definitely a crossroads for me when I was 17. I had just finished my junior year of high school, and I was working two part-time jobs to help my mom out. I was also on track to graduate early, which meant I could start college sooner. But my mom was really worried about the cost, and I felt the pressure to support the family. I remember sitting at the kitchen table one night, staring at my college application forms, and wondering if I could afford to go. I had a scholarship from a local community program, but it wasn't enough to cover everything. At the same time, my uncle, who had gone to college and was now a teacher, reached out and offered me a job as a tutor at his school. He said he believed in me and thought I could make a difference. I was torn. On one hand, I wanted to go to college and get a better future for myself. On the other hand, I didn't want to leave my mom alone, and I knew I could help her out right then. In the end, I chose to stay and work, and I tutored for two years while still finishing high school. That experience taught me a lot about responsibility, patience, and the value of education. It also showed me that I didn't need a college degree to make an impact. But I never stopped dreaming about going back to school. A few years later, I saved up enough to enroll in a community college part-time while working full-time. That decision, even though it wasn't the easy one, helped me grow into the person I am today — someone who values both education and hard work, and who knows that sometimes the right path isn't the most obvious one.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Jessica Johnson: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. I remember lying awake at night, thinking about what would happen if I left and what would happen if I stayed. I didn't want to regret not taking the chance to go to college, but I also didn't want to abandon my mom when she needed me most. In the end, I felt like I was making a choice that honored both my responsibilities and my dreams. I didn't just 'fall into' the decision — I weighed the pros and cons, talked to people I trusted, and made a plan. That experience taught me that even when life feels like it's pushing you in one direction, you can still take control and make a choice that aligns with your values. It wasn't easy, but it was mine, and that made all the difference.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Jessica Johnson: Absolutely. I remember reaching out to a local nonprofit that provided mentorship and financial assistance to students in my situation. They connected me with a counselor who helped me explore my options and even applied for some grants I didn't know existed. Without their support, I might have felt completely stuck. It was also my uncle who encouraged me to keep my college dreams alive, even if I had to take a different route for a while. I think it's really important for people in tough situations to know they don't have to go through it alone. There are often resources and people who want to help, even if you don't see them at first.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Jessica Johnson: Right now, I'm single and don't have any children. My mom is still a huge part of my life, and we talk almost every day. She's been through a lot, but she's strong and resilient, just like I am. I also have a younger brother who's in college, and I try to support him whenever I can, whether it's helping with expenses or just being there to listen. I don't have a partner right now because I've been focused on building my career and making sure I'm in a stable place before taking on more responsibilities. I do hope to one day find someone who shares my values and supports my goals, but for now, I'm content with where I am. Family has always been my anchor, and I know that no matter what, they'll always have my back.

Going through the interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, especially that crossroads at 17. It wasn't easy to stay and support my mom instead of going to college right away, but that decision taught me the value of responsibility and the strength of making choices that align with my values. I'm grateful for the support I received from my uncle and the local nonprofit — it reminded me that I don't have to face challenges alone. Looking back on my life story, I see how my early struggles built a strong foundation for who I am today. I'm proud of the person I've become, and I know that even though I'm still figuring out what's next, I have the resilience and determination to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Jessica Johnson: My dad isn't really a big part of my life anymore. He moved out when I was young, and we didn't stay in touch much after that. I remember him being around for the first few years, but things got complicated after the divorce, and he just kind of faded out. I don't hold any resentment toward him — I know he had his own struggles — but I also know that my mom and I had to rely on each other. I have a few cousins on my mom's side, and we keep in touch sometimes. They live in different parts of the country, but we make an effort to get together during holidays or special occasions. I also have an aunt who's pretty close to my mom, and she's been a big support system for us over the years. She's the one who helped my mom with childcare when I was working so much in high school. I'm grateful for her, because she made sure my mom didn't have to worry about everything on her own. Family has always been about showing up, even when things aren't perfect, and I think that's something I've carried with me throughout my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Jessica Johnson: I have a few close friends who have been there for me through thick and thin. One of them, Tasha, I met in high school through a community service project. We bonded over our shared experiences of growing up in tough circumstances, and she's been like a sister to me ever since. She's the one who encouraged me to apply for that scholarship and helped me prepare for the interviews. Even though we both took different paths after high school — she went to college right away while I stayed to work — we still keep in touch and support each other. I also have a coworker, Marcus, who I've known for a few years now. He's been a great mentor in my current job, and I look up to him for his work ethic and dedication. Outside of work and family, I also enjoy spending time with my friends at local community events or just hanging out at the park. I think it's important to have people in your life who lift you up, especially when things get tough. I'm really grateful for the people who have been in my corner, because they've helped me stay grounded and keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Jessica Johnson: I live in a neighborhood in Raleigh that's pretty diverse and full of life. It's a mix of older homes and newer apartments, and there's always something going on — from community events at the local park to small businesses popping up on the main street. I've lived here for a few years now, and I've come to really appreciate the sense of community here. There are a lot of people who are working hard, just like me, and I feel like we all have a shared understanding of what it takes to make it. The area isn't perfect — there are some parts that could use more investment, and I know the city is trying to address that — but overall, it feels like a place where people are building something together. I like that I can walk to a lot of places, and there are plenty of places to grab a good meal or grab a coffee with friends. It's not fancy, but it's home, and I feel like I'm part of something bigger here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Jessica Johnson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a strong sense of community, and people look out for each other. I've never had any real issues with crime, and I know most of my neighbors by name. There are always kids playing in the park, and I see the same faces at the local grocery store or coffee shop. That familiarity makes me feel secure. Of course, there are always challenges — like any neighborhood — but I think the people here are resilient and committed to making it a better place. I've seen initiatives come up to improve lighting in the streets and increase police presence when needed. It's not perfect, but I feel like I can walk outside at night without too much worry, and that gives me peace of mind.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Jessica Johnson: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the upside, I love the sense of community and how people here are always willing to help each other out. I've met some really great neighbors who I can count on, whether it's borrowing a cup of sugar or just having a conversation over the fence. The local park is a big part of my life — I go there almost every day to clear my head, read a book, or just sit and watch the kids play. It's a peaceful place that reminds me of the importance of slowing down and enjoying the little things. On the downside, there are definitely moments when I feel the weight of the cost of living here. Rent has gone up a bit over the years, and even with my full-time job, it's sometimes tight. I also know that not everyone in the neighborhood has the same opportunities I do, and that's something I think about a lot. I want to be part of the solution, whether it's volunteering with local youth programs or just being a voice for those who don't have one. Overall, though, I'm grateful for the stability this place has given me, and I know that no matter what, I have a home here — and that's something I don't take for granted.

Going through the interview questions about my family, relationships, and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my support system has shaped my life. Talking about my mom, brother, and the people who have been there for me reminded me of how important it is to have people who believe in you, even when things are tough. It also made me think about how my neighborhood has become a second home to me — a place where I feel safe, connected, and part of something bigger. Even though there are challenges, like the rising cost of living, I'm grateful for the sense of community and the people who make this place feel like home. I've come to realize that no matter where I go, the relationships I've built and the values I've held onto are what truly define who I am.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Jessica Johnson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on work and personal commitments. I work full-time at a local nonprofit that focuses on youth development, so most of my days start early — usually around 6:30 a.m. I try to get up before the kids in the neighborhood, so I can have a quiet moment with my coffee and a book. Mondays are usually the busiest day at work, with meetings and planning for the week ahead. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about implementing programs and working directly with the kids. Thursdays tend to be a bit slower, which is when I like to catch up on personal stuff — maybe go to the gym, do some errands, or meet up with Tasha for lunch. Fridays are my favorite because I get to wrap up the week and spend some time with my mom or my brother. On the weekends, I like to relax, maybe go to the park, do some volunteering, or just stay in and watch a movie. I also make sure to set aside time for self-care, whether it's taking a walk, journaling, or just enjoying the little things that make me feel grounded. Life can be busy, but I try to keep a balance so I don't burn out. It's not always perfect, but I feel like I'm living intentionally, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Jessica Johnson: I work full-time at a local nonprofit called 'Bright Futures,' which focuses on youth development and after-school programs for kids in our neighborhood. I'm a program coordinator, so my days are spent planning activities, managing volunteers, and working directly with the kids. I usually start my workday around 7:00 a.m., which means I have to be up by 6:30 to get ready and get to the office on time. The job is demanding, but I love it because I get to see the impact we're making — whether it's helping a kid with homework, teaching them new skills, or just being there to listen. I work Monday through Friday, with some occasional weekends when we have special events or community outreach programs. It's not always easy balancing work and everything else in my life, but I've learned to prioritize and manage my time well. This job has become more than just a paycheck for me — it's a way to give back to the community that helped raise me, and that means a lot.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Jessica Johnson: Outside of work, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. Every evening, no matter how busy my day has been, I try to take a 20-minute walk around the neighborhood. It's my way of unwinding and reflecting on the day. I also make it a point to journal a few times a week — not for anything formal, but just to write down my thoughts, my goals, and the things I'm grateful for. It helps me stay focused on what's important. I also have a small garden in the back of my apartment where I grow some herbs and a few vegetables. It's not much, but it's something I can call my own, and it reminds me of the importance of taking care of things, even in small ways. I also try to set aside time each week to volunteer with the same nonprofit I work for, whether it's helping out at an event or mentoring one of the kids in the program. It's not always easy to juggle everything, but I believe in the power of consistency — doing a little bit every day adds up over time, and that's something I've learned from my mom and from my own experiences.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Jessica Johnson: One recent change to my daily routine has been starting my mornings a little earlier to practice mindfulness and meditation. I've been feeling the weight of work and life responsibilities more than usual, so I decided to incorporate a short meditation session into my morning routine. I use a guided app, and it's been helping me stay centered and focused. I also started preparing meals in advance on weekends to save time during the week — it's been a small but meaningful shift that's helped me feel more in control of my schedule. I've also been trying to spend more time with my mom on the weekends, whether it's going to the grocery store together or just sitting down for a quiet dinner. It's been a nice reminder of how important it is to slow down and cherish the moments we have with the people we love.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Jessica Johnson: I don't have children of my own yet, but I've been thinking a lot about what it would be like to raise a child in a neighborhood like this. If I did, I imagine their days would start early, maybe with a breakfast routine that includes some kind of healthy meal, followed by getting ready for school. They'd probably ride the bus to a local school, and after school, they'd have some kind of activity — maybe sports, art, or something like the after-school programs I work with at Bright Futures. I think it's really important for kids to have structure and opportunities to explore their interests, especially in a community where resources can be limited. I've seen so many kids in our programs who have the potential to do great things, and I hope that if I ever have children, I can provide them with the same kind of support and encouragement that I've received from others in my life.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my relationships, neighborhood, and daily routines shape the person I am today. Talking about my family reminded me of the strength and support I've always had, even during the toughest times. My mom, brother, and the people who have stood by me have been my foundation, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. Thinking about my neighborhood made me realize how much of a role community plays in our well-being — it's not just a place to live, but a place where people care for one another and work together to build something better. My job at Bright Futures is more than just a career; it's a way to give back to the community that raised me, and I feel lucky to be part of it. My daily routines, from morning walks to journaling and gardening, are small but meaningful ways I stay grounded and connected to what matters most. Life is busy, but I've learned that living intentionally — making time for family, work, and self-care — is what helps me stay balanced and keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Jessica Johnson: In terms of my health, I would say I'm pretty active for the most part, but I've had my share of challenges over the years. Growing up in a household where money was tight, we didn't always have access to the best healthcare or nutritious food, and I think that had an impact on me. I used to struggle with stress-related issues, especially during the years when I was working two jobs and trying to keep up with school. I remember having trouble sleeping and feeling constantly tired, which made it harder to focus on my responsibilities. But over time, I've learned to take better care of myself. I started incorporating more exercise into my routine, like walking and yoga, which has helped with both my physical and mental well-being. I also try to eat as healthily as I can, even on a budget — things like cooking at home, buying seasonal produce, and making sure I get enough protein and vegetables. I've also been seeing a therapist occasionally, which has been really helpful in managing stress and staying grounded. I know I'm not perfect, and there are days when I slip up, but I've come to see health as something I have to work at every day — not just a one-time fix. It's one of the things I want to pass on to the kids I work with, because I know how much it can shape your life, especially when you're growing up in a community where resources aren't always easy to come by.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Jessica Johnson: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine and knowing the importance of small, consistent habits. I've found that walking every morning, even if it's just around the block, helps me start the day with a sense of calm and focus. I also find that cooking at home, even on a budget, gives me more control over what I eat, and I've learned to make healthy meals that are both satisfying and affordable. What makes it hard, though, is the stress that comes with balancing work, family, and personal goals. There are days when I'm so busy that I skip meals or don't get enough rest, and that can take a toll on my energy and mood. I've also had to learn to be kind to myself when I slip up — like when I grab a fast-food meal on a really busy day or forget to go to the gym. I know that staying healthy isn't about being perfect, but about showing up for yourself every day, even when it's hard. It's something I'm still learning, but I'm committed to it because I know how much it affects not just my own life, but the lives of the kids I work with too.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Jessica Johnson: In the past two years, I actually had a minor surgery for a herniated disc in my lower back. It wasn't something I was expecting — I had been dealing with some persistent lower back pain for a while, especially after long days at work and the occasional weekend volunteering. At first, I tried to push through it, thinking it was just stress or poor posture, but it started affecting my ability to walk long distances or sit for extended periods. Eventually, I made an appointment with a doctor, and after some tests, they recommended the surgery. It was a bit scary, but I knew I had to take care of it before it got worse. The recovery was tough — I had to take a few weeks off work and rely on my mom and Tasha to help me with daily tasks. But honestly, it was one of the best decisions I made. Now that I'm healed, I feel more energized and able to keep up with my routine. It also made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signs. I've since started incorporating more stretching and strengthening exercises into my daily walk, and I'm even thinking about trying Pilates to build better core strength. It's a reminder that health is something you have to actively maintain, and I'm more committed to that than ever before.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Jessica Johnson: Honestly, the surgery was a wake-up call for me. For a while, I was worried it would affect my ability to work, especially since my job involves a lot of standing and moving around with the kids. But the recovery went better than I expected, and I actually felt more motivated to take care of my body after that experience. It didn't stop me from working, and if anything, it made me more aware of how important it is to take breaks and not push myself too hard. I think the biggest challenge was adjusting to the temporary limitations — like not being able to walk as much or lift things without pain. But with the support of my mom and Tasha, I got through it. It also made me more empathetic toward the kids I work with who might be dealing with their own health issues or challenges. I want them to know that it's okay to ask for help and that taking care of yourself isn't a weakness — it's a strength.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Jessica Johnson: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things — mostly gratitude, but also a sense of growth and reflection. It's been a year of learning to balance more than ever before, especially with my work, my health, and my personal goals. I've been really proud of how I've handled the recovery from my surgery — it wasn't easy, but it taught me a lot about patience and self-care. I've also been thinking a lot about my future, and I've started looking into continuing my education again. I've enrolled in some online courses through the community college, and it's been exciting to revisit learning in a new way. I feel more confident now than I did when I was 17, and that's something I'm really grateful for. I've also been trying to be more present in my relationships — whether it's with my mom, my brother, or my friends — and I think that's made a big difference in how I feel overall. Life is still busy, but I'm starting to feel more in control of it, and that gives me a lot of peace.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines have shaped my journey over the years. Thinking about my recent changes, like starting mindfulness practices and meal prepping, reminded me of how small, intentional habits can make a big difference in how I feel and function. It also made me realize how important it is to prioritize my well-being, not just for myself, but for the people I care about and the work I do. Talking about my health struggles, like the herniated disc surgery, was a bit vulnerable, but it also showed me how far I've come and how much I've learned about listening to my body. I'm proud of the progress I've made, and I know that continuing to take care of myself — both physically and mentally — is one of the most important things I can do for my future.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Jessica Johnson: I think I've had my moments of feeling overwhelmed, especially during the years when I was juggling work, school, and taking care of my mom. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders, and I didn't know how to ask for help. I remember feeling really anxious during those periods — like I was always one step away from falling apart. But over time, I've learned to recognize those feelings and not let them define me. I started talking to a therapist a few years back, and that was a game-changer for me. It helped me understand that it's okay to feel anxious or stressed, and that seeking help isn't a sign of weakness. I've also found comfort in my faith — being part of my church community has given me a sense of peace and reminded me that I'm not alone in this. I still have days when things feel heavy, but I've come to see those moments as part of the journey, not as something to be ashamed of. I want the kids I work with to know that it's okay to feel this way, and that there's always a way forward — even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Jessica Johnson: For my family, the past year has been a mix of challenges and small victories. My mom has been doing better, physically and emotionally. She's started going to the community center for some of the health and wellness programs they offer, and it's been good for her to have that space to take care of herself. She still works part-time, but she's more focused on her own well-being now, which I think is really important. My brother is in his second year of college, and he's been managing pretty well, though he's had to take on some extra work to help with expenses. I've been trying to support him as much as I can, whether it's helping with his bills or just being there to listen when he needs to talk. We've had some tough conversations, especially about the future and what it means to be independent, but I think we're both learning from each other. For my family, it's been about finding strength in each other and remembering that even in the hardest times, we're not alone.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Jessica Johnson: For me, religion has always been a source of strength and comfort, especially during the tough times. Being part of the Protestant church in our community has given me a sense of belonging and purpose. I grew up going to church with my mom, and even though we didn't go every week, the values we learned there — like kindness, forgiveness, and resilience — have stayed with me throughout my life. I think faith helps me stay grounded, especially when things feel overwhelming. It's not about being perfect or having all the answers, but more about finding peace in the journey and trusting that there's a bigger plan. I also find comfort in prayer and reading scripture, especially when I'm struggling with stress or uncertainty. I know not everyone shares my beliefs, and that's okay. What matters to me is that I have something to hold onto — something that reminds me I'm not alone, even when life feels heavy. I want the kids I work with to know that it's okay to have faith, to ask for help, and to believe in something bigger than themselves, even if it's just the strength of their own community.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Jessica Johnson: I don't use social media too often, honestly. I've found that it can be a bit overwhelming with all the noise and comparisons, and I prefer to keep my focus on the people and things that matter most to me. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family and friends, especially my cousins and my mom's side of the family. I also follow a few local community pages that post about events, job opportunities, and volunteer needs — it's a good way to stay connected to what's happening in our neighborhood. I don't really use Instagram or TikTok, mostly because I feel like they're more for younger people or for showing off, and I don't really want to be on that kind of platform. I think it's important to be present in real life, and I've found that limiting my time online helps me stay more grounded. Plus, I have enough to keep me busy with work, family, and my own personal goals — I don't need to add more distractions to my life.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Jessica Johnson: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support during tough times, but I know it can be a lifeline for some people. For me, it's always been the people in my life — my mom, my friends, and the community — who have been my support system. That said, I do think social media can be a double-edged sword. I've seen how it can connect people and provide resources, especially for those who might feel isolated or don't have a strong support network. I remember a few years back when I was going through a really tough time with work and my health, and I saw some posts from local groups that offered mental health resources or financial assistance. I didn't use them myself, but it was comforting to know they were out there. I think it's important to use these platforms wisely — not to compare yourself to others, but to find the people and information that can truly help you. I just hope that when the kids I work with are going through their own struggles, they know that support is available in many forms, whether it's online or in person.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and emotional well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my herniated disc surgery was a bit vulnerable, but it also showed me how far I've come and how much I've learned about listening to my body. It reminded me that health is something you have to actively maintain, and I'm more committed to that than ever before. It also made me think about my mental health — the times I've felt overwhelmed, anxious, or stressed, and how important it is to seek help when needed. I've learned that it's okay to feel this way, and that seeking support isn't a weakness. I'm grateful for the progress I've made, and I know that continuing to take care of myself — both physically and mentally — is one of the most important things I can do for my future.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Jessica Johnson: Over the past year, I've been working on managing my stress and worry in more intentional ways. I used to carry a lot of it silently, thinking I had to handle everything on my own. But I've learned that it's okay to ask for help, and I've started opening up more to my mom, Tasha, and even my therapist when things feel overwhelming. One of the biggest changes has been incorporating mindfulness into my daily routine — even if it's just a few minutes of deep breathing or a short meditation. It helps me stay grounded, especially when I'm feeling stretched thin between work, my health, and my personal goals. I've also started journaling more regularly, not just to track my thoughts, but to process them. It's amazing how writing things down can help me see things more clearly and release some of the weight I've been carrying. I'm still learning, and there are definitely days when I feel like I'm back to square one, but I'm more aware now of how my emotional health affects everything else in my life. I want to model that for the kids I work with — showing them that it's okay to feel stressed, but it's also important to find healthy ways to cope.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Jessica Johnson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is the largest chunk of my budget — I live in a small apartment that's manageable but doesn't leave much room for extras. Groceries are another big one, especially since I try to eat healthily and cook at home as much as possible. I also have a monthly bus pass for getting to work and running errands, and that adds up over time. I also set aside money for utilities, insurance, and some savings, even if it's just a little each month. I don't have a lot to spare, but I try to be intentional with every dollar. I've learned to prioritize what's essential — like making sure I have enough food and a safe place to live — and I've cut back on things I don't need, like eating out or buying things on impulse. It's not always easy, but I know that being responsible with my money helps me stay stable and gives me the freedom to support my mom and my brother when they need it. I also try to set aside a little bit each month for unexpected expenses, just in case something comes up. It's all about balance — making sure I can take care of myself while still being there for the people I love.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Jessica Johnson: Last month, my household spent around $1,800, which is pretty close to what I usually spend each month. The breakdown is mostly the same — about $800 on rent, $400 on groceries, and $200 on transportation and utilities. I also set aside around $150 for savings and unexpected expenses, and the rest goes toward insurance and other small bills. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep things running smoothly. I've learned to be really careful with my money, especially since I want to make sure I can support my mom and my brother when they need it. I also try to budget for things like gifts or special occasions, even if it's just a small amount. It's all about making the most of what I have and knowing that every dollar counts — especially when you're building a life on your own.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Jessica Johnson: We rent our home. I live in a small apartment in a neighborhood I've come to love — it's not fancy, but it's comfortable and close to everything I need. Renting has been the practical choice for me, especially since I'm still working to build up my savings and pay off some of the expenses I've had over the years, like my surgery. I know that owning a home is a goal for many people, and I hope to one day be in a position where that's possible. For now, though, renting gives me the flexibility I need to focus on my job, my family, and my personal growth. I've learned to appreciate the little things about my apartment — the way the sunlight comes in during the morning, the quiet of the neighborhood at night, and the fact that I can walk to work or the grocery store in just a few minutes. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Jessica Johnson: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter, my heating bill went up a bit, which was a challenge since I was already trying to stretch my budget as much as possible. I remember having to choose between buying a new sweater or paying the extra for heat, and I ended up getting a second blanket and wearing layers more often. Then, in the spring, when the weather got nicer, I started spending a little more on things like flowers for my apartment and a few small home improvements — like painting a room a fresh color. That was a nice way to treat myself after a tough winter. During the holidays, my expenses went up a bit more, especially when I wanted to give my mom and brother something thoughtful. I had to be careful not to overspend, so I set a strict limit for myself and focused on meaningful, affordable gifts. I also noticed that my transportation costs stayed pretty steady throughout the year, but I did save a bit when I started biking to work more often on nice days. Overall, it's been about adjusting and being flexible — knowing that some months will be tighter than others, but also finding little ways to make the most of what I have.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and the support systems around me have helped me navigate the challenges of the past year. Talking about my mom's progress and my brother's journey in college reminded me of how important it is to lean on each other during tough times. It also made me think about how I've come to rely less on social media for support and more on the real, tangible connections I have with people in my life. I've seen how social media can be both a tool and a distraction, and I'm grateful that I've found my strength in the people who are physically present — my family, my friends, and my community. I hope that the kids I work with understand that support comes in many forms, and that sometimes the best help is the one you find right at home.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Jessica Johnson: I do save, though it's not always a lot — more like a little here and there, but it adds up over time. I have a small savings account that I try to contribute to every month, even if it's just $50 or $100. It's not much, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that I have something set aside for emergencies or unexpected expenses. I also try to save in other ways, like buying secondhand clothes or using coupons when I shop. I remember when I was younger, I didn't think about saving much because I was focused on just getting by. But now I see how important it is to have a financial cushion, especially when you're supporting family or planning for the future. I've also started setting aside a little bit each month for my own goals, like going back to school or maybe even buying a car someday. It's not about having a lot — it's about being prepared and knowing that even small steps can lead to bigger things.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Jessica Johnson: For me, saving in the last year has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. I've been trying to build a safety net so that if something comes up — like another medical expense or a sudden need to help my mom or brother — I don't have to scramble to find the money. I also started saving a little bit each month for my own goals, like going back to school part-time. It's not a huge amount, but it's something I can count on. I think it's important to have that sense of security, especially when you're working hard and trying to support others. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about big numbers — it's about being responsible with what you have and knowing that even small contributions can add up over time. It's one of the things I want to teach the kids I work with too — that planning for the future, even in small ways, can make a big difference in the long run.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Jessica Johnson: My occupation is a Program Coordinator at a local nonprofit called 'Bright Futures,' where I focus on youth development and after-school programs for kids in our neighborhood. My days are spent planning activities, managing volunteers, and working directly with the kids — whether it's helping them with homework, teaching them new skills, or just being there to listen. The most important part of my job is creating a safe and supportive environment where these kids can thrive, especially since many of them come from backgrounds similar to mine. I want them to know that no matter where they're from or what challenges they're facing, they have the potential to achieve great things. It's not always easy — there are days when I feel overwhelmed with the demands of the job, but seeing the kids grow and succeed makes it all worth it. I've learned that leadership isn't just about managing programs; it's about being a role model, showing up consistently, and believing in the people you're working with. This job has become more than just a paycheck for me — it's a way to give back to the community that helped raise me, and that means a lot.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Jessica Johnson: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch a bit longer depending on the season or special events we have. Mondays through Fridays are my core workdays, and I'm often in the office by 7:00 a.m. to get everything set up for the kids. There are weeks when I stay late to wrap up projects or meet with volunteers, and I've learned to be flexible with my time. I also take on some extra responsibilities, like leading workshops or organizing community outreach, which can add a few hours here and there. It's not always easy balancing work with everything else in my life — my mom, my brother, and my personal goals — but I've gotten really good at prioritizing and managing my time. I know that showing up consistently is one of the most important things I can do for the kids I work with, and that's something I take very seriously.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Jessica Johnson: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. For a while after high school, I worked two part-time jobs to help my mom out, but that was before I started working full-time at Bright Futures. I remember working at a local bookstore in the mornings and then doing some administrative work for a small business in the afternoons. It was tough, but I learned a lot about time management and responsibility. Once I got the job at Bright Futures, I realized that working full-time was the right path for me — not just because it pays better, but because it allows me to focus on something that truly matters to me. I've been lucky to have a stable job that gives me the flexibility to support my family and still take care of myself. I know not everyone has that luxury, which is why I try to be as present and committed as I can be in my role — because I know how much it can mean to someone who's trying to build a better life.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about my stress, coping strategies, and how I manage my monthly budget reminded me of how interconnected these aspects of my life are. I've come to realize that taking care of my mental health isn't just about personal well-being — it also affects how I handle my responsibilities, support my family, and stay focused on my goals. It's also made me think about how important it is to be intentional with my money, not just for myself, but for the people I care about. I'm proud of the progress I've made in both areas, and I know that continuing to prioritize my health and financial planning will help me build a stronger, more stable future for myself and those I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Jessica Johnson: In total, my household made around $2,400 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary at Bright Futures, which covers most of the expenses, and a small part-time gig I took on at a local community center to help with weekend events. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep things running and give me some extra flexibility. I've learned to be really careful with my money, especially since I want to make sure I can support my mom and my brother when they need it. I also try to set aside a little bit each month for unexpected expenses, just in case something comes up. It's all about balance — making sure I can take care of myself while still being there for the people I love.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Jessica Johnson: I've been at Bright Futures for about three years now, and it's been one of the most rewarding experiences of my life. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit — we have health insurance, which is a huge relief, especially after my surgery. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which is something I used a lot during my recovery. I also really appreciate the flexibility they offer, like the ability to work remotely on certain days or adjust my schedule when needed. One of the best parts about working here is the sense of purpose — knowing that what I do every day directly impacts the kids in our community. I've seen so many of them grow into confident, capable young adults, and that gives me a lot of fulfillment. I know not everyone in nonprofits gets the same level of support, but I'm really grateful for the opportunities I've had here, and I hope to keep growing with the organization as much as I can.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Jessica Johnson: My relationships at work are really positive — I feel supported by both my manager and my coworkers. My manager, Ms. Thompson, is someone I really look up to. She's been in the nonprofit world for a long time, and she has this way of balancing leadership with empathy. She's always encouraging me to take on new challenges, but also knows when to step back and let me figure things out on my own. I think that's what makes her such a good leader — she trusts her team and believes in their potential. As for my coworkers, we have a really strong bond. We've been through a lot together — late nights, tough projects, and even some personal struggles — and that creates a sense of loyalty and understanding. We're not just coworkers; we're a team, and I feel like I can count on any of them. I think that kind of support is rare, especially in a nonprofit setting where the work can be demanding, but I'm really grateful for it. It makes coming to work every day feel like more than just a job — it feels like being part of something meaningful.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Jessica Johnson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a good amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. I usually start at 7:00 a.m. and work until around 3:30 p.m., but depending on the day, I might stay a bit later to wrap up meetings or prepare for the next day's activities. There are times when I need to adjust my hours — like if we have a special event or if a kid needs extra support — and my manager is always understanding about that. I also get the option to work from home a couple of days a week, which is a huge help when I need to take care of personal things or just need a little more time to recharge. I think that balance between structure and flexibility is what makes this job work for me — it allows me to be consistent with my responsibilities while still having the freedom to manage my life in a way that feels sustainable.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Jessica Johnson: Overall, I feel pretty stable with my financial situation, but I know there's always room for growth. I'm not living in luxury, but I'm not struggling either — I have a roof over my head, I can put food on the table, and I'm able to support my mom and my brother when they need it. That gives me a lot of peace of mind. I also know that I'm in a better position than a lot of people in my neighborhood, and I try to use that to my advantage by being responsible with my money and planning for the future. I've learned that financial stability isn't about having a lot — it's about having enough to feel secure and being able to make choices that matter. I'm still working on building more savings and maybe even going back to school part-time, but I feel like I'm on the right path. It's not always easy, but I'm proud of how far I've come, and I know that with time and consistency, I can keep moving forward.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work life have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of being flexible and adaptable — some months are tighter than others, but I've learned to make the most of what I have. It also made me think about how my job at Bright Futures has given me a sense of stability, even if it's not always easy. I'm proud of the fact that I've been able to save a little each month, even if it's not a lot, and I know that those small steps add up over time. I've also come to appreciate the balance my job offers — the structure of a 40-hour workweek, the flexibility to adjust when needed, and the support I receive from my manager and coworkers. It's not perfect, but it's enough to keep me going and to help me support the people I care about. I'm grateful for the progress I've made, and I know that with time and consistency, I can keep building a stronger, more stable future for myself and those I love.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Jessica Johnson: Yes, my mom worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up, and honestly, she worked pretty consistently throughout most of my childhood. She had a part-time job at a local grocery store, and later she moved to a different position at a community center where she could get benefits and some flexibility. It wasn't easy — she was working long hours, often coming home exhausted, but she always made sure I had what I needed. I remember her trying to balance work with taking care of me and my brother, and sometimes she had to work double shifts just to make ends meet. I think that's one of the reasons I learned to be so independent at a young age — I saw how hard she worked, and I didn't want to be a burden. It also made me really appreciate the value of a steady job and the importance of supporting your family. I hope to one day be in a position where I can provide that same kind of stability for my own family, if and when that time comes.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Jessica Johnson: My mom's job was at a local community center, and she worked with families in similar situations to ours — people who were trying to make ends meet, raise kids, and build a better life. Her most important duties were helping organize after-school programs for kids, providing support to parents, and making sure everyone felt seen and heard. She had a way of connecting with people, and I think that's what made her so good at her job. She wasn't just doing the work — she was genuinely caring about the people she served. I remember seeing her come home tired, but also proud of the difference she was making. It taught me that even in the toughest times, you can still find purpose in your work. I think that's why I ended up in the same kind of work — because I know how much it can mean to someone who's just trying to get by.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Jessica Johnson: My mom worked for a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' which focused on providing support services to low-income families, including after-school programs, parenting classes, and food assistance. It was a small but impactful place — not a lot of resources, but the people there were passionate about what they did. She was one of the program coordinators, which meant she was responsible for organizing activities for kids, coordinating with local schools, and making sure families had access to the resources they needed. She also worked closely with other community leaders to advocate for better services and policies that would help people like us. I remember seeing her come home with stories about the kids she worked with — some of them had really tough lives, just like we did, but she always found a way to make them feel seen and supported. That's something I carry with me to this day, because it's what inspired me to go into the same kind of work. Even though she didn't make a lot of money, she always said that the real reward was knowing she was making a difference, and I think that's what kept her going through the hardest times.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Jessica Johnson: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in this neighborhood, still working at Bright Futures, but maybe with more responsibility and a bigger role in shaping the programs that help kids like the ones I work with every day. I also hope I've been able to go back to school part-time and maybe earn a degree in social work or something related to youth development — not just for my own growth, but so I can have more tools to help others. I want to be in a place where I can provide stability for my mom and my brother, maybe even help my mom retire comfortably after all the years she sacrificed for us. I also hope I'm still surrounded by the same people who have supported me — my mom, Tasha, Marcus, and the rest of my community. I want to be someone who others can look up to, just like my mom was to me. I know the road isn't going to be easy, but I believe in the power of consistency, hard work, and staying true to your values. I hope that in a few years, I can look back and know that I made the right choices — not just for myself, but for the people I care about and the community that raised me.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Jessica Johnson: What I value the most in my life is the strength of relationships — the people who show up, even when things are hard. My mom, my friends, my coworkers, and the kids I work with — they're all part of what makes me who I am. I value the sense of community we have here in Raleigh, the way people look out for each other, and the way we support one another through challenges. I also value resilience — the ability to keep going, even when life feels heavy. I've seen that in my mom, in my brother, and in the kids I work with every day. And I value the chance to give back, to be part of something bigger than myself. I know I didn't have everything growing up, but I also know I had the support of people who believed in me, and that's something I carry with me every day. I hope to always be someone who lifts others up, just like I was lifted up when I needed it most.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial stability and work life have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about my monthly income and how I make ends meet reminded me of the importance of being intentional with every dollar, especially when supporting my family. It also made me think about how my job at Bright Futures has given me a sense of purpose and structure, even if it's not always easy. I'm proud of the fact that I've been able to save a little each month, even if it's not a lot, and I know that those small steps add up over time. I've also come to appreciate the balance my job offers — the structure of a 40-hour workweek, the flexibility to adjust when needed, and the support I receive from my manager and coworkers. It's not perfect, but it's enough to keep me going and to help me support the people I care about. I'm grateful for the progress I've made, and I know that with time and consistency, I can keep building a stronger, more stable future for myself and those I love.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just for the people who asked the questions, but for me as well. It's amazing how much of my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, the people who have supported me, and the challenges I've faced along the way. From my early years growing up in Raleigh, helping my mom make ends meet, to the crossroads I faced at 17 when I had to choose between college and staying to support my family, every experience has played a role in who I am today. I've learned that life isn't always about the easy path — sometimes the hardest decisions are the ones that build the strongest foundation. I'm proud of the person I've become — someone who values responsibility, community, and the power of education. I've also come to appreciate how much I've grown emotionally and financially, and how much I've learned about the importance of health, relationships, and resilience. This interview has reminded me that no matter how far I've come, there's always more to learn, more to grow, and more to give back to the people and community that have helped shape my journey. I'm grateful for every step of the way, and I'm ready to keep moving forward with the same strength and determination that have always defined me.
